content.title: software installation - How do I install a .deb file via the command line? - Ask Ubuntu
content.content:
# [How do I install a .deb file via the command line?](/questions/40779/how-do-i-install-a-deb-file-via-the-command-line)
   [Ask Question](/questions/ask)      Asked 14 years, 5 months ago   Modified [12 months ago](?lastactivity)   Viewed 5.5m times               1563               How do I install a .deb file via the command line?
     

- [command-line](/questions/tagged/command-line)

- [software-installation](/questions/tagged/software-installation)

          [Share](/q/40779)   [Improve this question](/posts/40779/edit)    Follow            [edited Sep 15, 2021 at 15:16](/posts/40779/revisions)       [Braiam](/users/169736/braiam)  69.3k3232 gold badges182182 silver badges278278 bronze badges         asked May 6, 2011 at 17:40       [TheXed](/users/3889/thexed)  27.8k1313 gold badges6262 silver badges8989 bronze badges           
 
- 7 Complete answer : [How to install a deb file, by dpkg -i or by apt?](https://unix.stackexchange.com/q/159094/86583) – [g_p](/users/146791/g-p) [Commented Dec 4, 2018 at 11:34](#comment1809539_40779)
 
- 1 Related: [How to let dpkg -i install dependencies for me?](https://askubuntu.com/questions/40011/how-to-let-dpkg-i-install-dependencies-for-me) – [Melebius](/users/250300/melebius) [Commented Jul 9, 2019 at 19:56](#comment1925662_40779)
 
- 1 I use gdebi sudo gdebi ./app.deb – [STEEL](/users/190274/steel) [Commented Mar 26, 2024 at 16:07](#comment2647060_40779)
 
   [Add a comment](#)            
##  12 Answers  
      Sorted by:       Highest score (default)   Date modified (newest first)   Date created (oldest first)                  1745                    Packages are **manually** installed via the **dpkg** command (Debian Package Management System). dpkg is the backend to commands like apt-get and aptitude, which in turn are the backend for GUI install apps like the Software Center and Synaptic.
 Something along the lines of:
 dpkg --> apt-get, aptitude --> Synaptic, Software Center
 But of course the easiest ways to install a package would be, first, the GUI apps (Synaptic, Software Center, etc..), followed by the terminal commands apt-get and aptitude that add a very nice user friendly approach to the backend dpkg, including but not limited to packaged dependencies, control over what is installed, needs update, not installed, broken packages, etc.. Lastly the dpkg command which is the base for all of them.
 Since dpkg is the base, you can use it to install packaged directly from the command line.
 
### Install a package
 sudo dpkg -i DEB_PACKAGE  For example if the package file is called askubuntu_2.0.deb then you should do sudo dpkg -i askubuntu_2.0.deb. If dpkg reports an error due to dependency problems, you can run sudo apt-get install -f to download the missing dependencies and configure everything. If that reports an error, you'll have to sort out the dependencies yourself by following for example [How do I resolve unmet dependencies after adding a PPA?](https://askubuntu.com/questions/140246/how-do-i-resolve-unmet-dependencies).
 
### Remove a package
 sudo dpkg -r PACKAGE_NAME  For example if the package is called askubuntu then you should do sudo dpkg -r askubuntu.
 
### Reconfigure an existing package
 sudo dpkg-reconfigure PACKAGE_NAME  This is useful when you need to reconfigure something related to said package. Some useful examples it the keyboard-configuration when you want to enable the Ctrl+Alt+Backspace in order to reset the X server, so you would the following:
 sudo dpkg-reconfigure keyboard-configuration  Another great one is when you need to set the Timezone for a server or your local testing computer, so you use use the tzdata package:
 sudo dpkg-reconfigure tzdata          [Share](/a/40781)   [Improve this answer](/posts/40781/edit)    Follow            [edited Apr 13, 2017 at 12:23](/posts/40781/revisions)       [Community](/users/-1/community)Bot  1         answered May 6, 2011 at 17:43       [Luis Alvarado](/users/7035/luis-alvarado)  217k172172 gold badges556556 silver badges727727 bronze badges           
 
- 5 Great info, had to find some way to install traceroute to help debug why my machine won't connect to the internet :) – [Jason](/users/145043/jason) [Commented Nov 20, 2013 at 15:01](#comment485182_40781)
 
- 37 Also helpful to note that once installed programs are usually found in /usr/bin, named after what was depackaged. – [Chris Moschini](/users/174686/chris-moschini) [Commented Mar 31, 2014 at 9:10](#comment576949_40781)
 
- If I run sudo apt-get install texlive-latex-base, it has failed for months with "Hash Sum mismatch". I can download the .deb file from http://gb.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/pool/main/t/texlive-base/texlive-latex-base-doc_2015.20150625-1ubuntu1_all.deb. If I install it using dpkg, would it subsequently be recognised (and updated) by apt-get. – [user643722](/users/110495/user643722) [Commented Jan 19, 2016 at 17:05](#comment1069393_40781)
 
- 3 If it's easier and better to install via aptitude or apt-get (or simply apt), why aren't examples for these commands given here? – [intuited](/users/3865/intuited) [Commented Nov 18, 2017 at 16:56](#comment1569977_40781)
 
- 4 With modern apt I would recommend doing sudo apt install ./package.deb instead. This allows automatically installing all the dependencies and it does all the extra sanity checks that dpkg will not implement because it's a low level command. Note that without the prefix / or ./ some versions of apt may not understand that you're trying to refer to file name, not a package name from repository. – [Mikko Rantalainen](/users/50254/mikko-rantalainen) [Commented Mar 14, 2023 at 12:18](#comment2552892_40781)
 
     [Show **3** more comments](#)                218                Debian (.deb) packages are the packages that are used in Ubuntu. You can install any .deb package in your system. .deb files can generally be installed from your file manager (Nautilus) merely by clicking on them, since file associations with the default installer is already set in Ubuntu. These instructions are for those who wish to install packages from the command-line terminal (Terminal).
 To install a downloaded Debian (Ubuntu) package (.deb): Open Terminal and type
 sudo dpkg -i packagename.deb  To remove a Debian (Ubuntu) package (.deb):
 sudo dpkg -r packagename  To Reconfigure/Repair an installed Debian (Ubuntu) package (.deb):
 sudo dpkg-reconfigure packagename          [Share](/a/225623)   [Improve this answer](/posts/225623/edit)    Follow            [edited Feb 1, 2024 at 15:37](/posts/225623/revisions)       [punkfairie](/users/1764539/punkfairie)  322 bronze badges         answered Dec 5, 2012 at 6:04       [Atul Makwana](/users/85015/atul-makwana)  2,45822 gold badges1515 silver badges1010 bronze badges           
 
- 4 clicking on them doesn't work as of Ubuntu 22, it opens them as an archive – [iopq](/users/685200/iopq) [Commented Feb 20, 2023 at 2:42](#comment2544602_225623)
 
   [Add a comment](#)                 131                While dpkg -i indeed installs the package, it doesn't do any automatic dependency resolution. Meanwhile there are two other alternatives, using gdebi or the apt-get tool. To use the latter just use:
 sudo apt-get install /path/to/package.deb  Even if you are on the directory with the package, you need to give a path using ./ at the start:
 sudo apt-get install ./package.deb          [Share](/a/769542)   [Improve this answer](/posts/769542/edit)    Follow            [edited Oct 16, 2024 at 13:52](/posts/769542/revisions)               answered May 8, 2016 at 23:48       [Braiam](/users/169736/braiam)  69.3k3232 gold badges182182 silver badges278278 bronze badges           
 
- 28 This is probably the best answer. apt will prevent you from breaking your​ system if you don't have the correct dependencies. – [mlainz](/users/689509/mlainz) [Commented May 15, 2017 at 22:04](#comment1442887_769542)
 
- This command seems to select all existing packages. – [Hibou57](/users/97838/hibou57) [Commented Sep 23, 2017 at 7:58](#comment1530932_769542)
 
- @Hibou57 there can't be any space in the package name. – [Braiam](/users/169736/braiam) [Commented Mar 5, 2018 at 20:18](#comment1640635_769542)
 
- I have an understanding apt-get will download and install latest deb from repos, to prevent that turn network off before install. Even cleaner install is by copying file (or several deb files together) to /var/cache/apt/archives and running sudo apt-get install --assume-yes --no-install-recommends /var/cache/apt/archives/*.deb, that way as I've noticed apt is not trying to download from internet. – [Alex Martian](/users/796396/alex-martian) [Commented Feb 12, 2023 at 8:45](#comment2541661_769542)
 
- if you get any missing packages warning use sudo apt-get install ./package.deb --fix-broken – [Nitin S](/users/19646/nitin-s) [Commented Dec 23, 2024 at 23:45](#comment2702572_769542)
 
     [Show **4** more comments](#)                128                My favourite is GDebi, available from both terminal/shell or graphical desktop.
 
 I usually associate .deb files with GDebi as it is fast and efficient - especially compared to Ubuntu Software Center. **One of the main feature of GDebi is it resolves dependencies and installs them.** 
 For command-line run sudo gdebi <package.deb> to install a single deb file.
         [Share](/a/170557)   [Improve this answer](/posts/170557/edit)    Follow            [edited Jun 3, 2014 at 10:43](/posts/170557/revisions)      ...
